column1: Angioedema is swelling that is similar to hives, but the swelling is under the skin instead of on the surface.
An HAE attack can result in rapid swelling of the hands, feet, limbs, face, intestinal tract, larynx (voicebox), or trachea (windpipe).

- Airway blockage -- involves throat swelling and sudden hoarseness - Repeat episodes of abdominal cramping without obvious cause - Swelling in the arms, legs, lips, eyes, tongue, or throat - Swelling of the intestines -- can be severe and lead to abdominal cramping, vomiting, dehydration, diarrhea, pain, and occasionally shock There is usually no itching or hives.
Antihistamines and other treatments used for angioedema do not work well for HAE.
Androgen medications, such as danazol, can reduce the frequency and severity of attacks.
